title: 107_hr2645
content: The Motor Donor Act, also known as the National Organ Donor Registry, amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national organ donor registry. The purposes of this subpart are to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, enhance information provided to individuals, ensure timely and accurate donation information availability. The subpart aims to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, provide timely and accurate donation information, and offer grants to states for establishing donor registries through driver's license applications. Definitions include motor vehicle driver's license and State. The Secretary will establish a national organ and tissue donor registry containing individuals' information like name, address, date of birth, sex, height, and eye color. The Motor Donor Act requires individuals to be organ or tissue donors by providing their personal information to a national registry established by the Secretary. Coordination with States and organ procurement organizations is mandated during the initial 2-year period after the enactment of the Act. During the 4-year period after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will work with States to establish organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. The registries will be operated by State agencies and linked to the national registry. States will promote and encourage the establishment of organ and tissue donor registries through the motor vehicle driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations will have 24-hour access to the Registry using a password assigned by the Secretary. Each organization must designate staff members to receive the password and access the Registry through a designated website. The Motor Donor Act requires organ procurement organizations to designate staff members to access the Registry using a password assigned by the Secretary. The Secretary will disseminate a pamphlet to US citizens with information on organ and tissue donations and a website address to participate in the Registry. The Motor Donor Act mandates organ procurement organizations to designate staff to access the Registry. Individuals can participate in the Registry through a website address provided in a pamphlet. The Secretary will notify individuals within 4 months of their participation. Participation in the Registry does not impact organ or tissue allocation practices. The Motor Donor Act requires organ procurement organizations to designate staff to access the Registry. Participation in the Registry does not affect organ or tissue allocation practices. The Registry serves as an individual's intent to donate organs or tissues, and participation is not legally binding consent except as provided by State law. Individuals can request to cancel their participation. The Motor Donor Act allows individuals to participate in the Registry to express their intent to donate organs or tissues. Participation is not legally binding consent, except as allowed by State law. Individuals have the right to cancel their participation at any time, and the Secretary will promptly remove their information from the Registry upon request. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to States for this purpose. The Secretary can award grants to States for implementing State registries linked to the motor vehicle driver's license application process. States must submit applications to the Secretary to be eligible for these grants. Each application submitted under subparagraph (A) must demonstrate how the State will establish procedures for individuals to make legally binding gifts for organ and tissue donation when applying for a driver's license. The State procedures for driver's license applications must include assurances that comply with specific requirements. The State driver's license application must allow individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The State driver's license application must include a question asking if the individual wishes to have their organ donor designation on their driver's license or in the State registry, with only affirmative responses being noted. The State procedures require individuals to have their organ donor preference noted on their driver's license or in the State registry, with the information forwarded to the Registry within 100 days of designation. The State procedures mandate that individuals must have their organ donor preference recorded on their driver's license or in the State registry within 100 days of designation, with any changes in designation or address information also being updated with the Registry. Individuals who choose not to have their organ donor designation included will not have their name forwarded to the Registry. The State procedures require individuals to have their organ donor preference recorded on their driver's license or in the State registry within 100 days. Information of those who opt in will be accessible 24/7 by the State agency. The State agency provides 24-hour access to donor information to organ procurement organizations without any fees. Priority in grant awards is given to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded under this subsection have limitations. The State agency provides 24-hour access to donor information to organ procurement organizations without fees. Grants awarded under this subsection have limitations, with no grant exceeding $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, is established. The advisory task force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience in organ donations, procurement, or transplants, with at least 1 member being a physician. At least 1 member of the Task Force must be a physician experienced in organ transplants, and another member must have experience in organ procurement. Members serve a 3-year term and may be reappointed. The Task Force members serve staggered 2-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force can partner with the Coalition on Donation. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation to enhance the national awareness campaign for the Registry and submit recommendations for its improvement to the Secretary within a year of the Motor Donor Act enactment. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation to enhance the national awareness campaign for the Registry and submit recommendations for its improvement to the Secretary within a year of the Motor Donor Act enactment. The Task Force report contains recommendations for improving the Registry, increasing public awareness about organ and tissue donation, and improving the donation process. Members of the Task Force do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Task Force members are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, while performing services. The Secretary can accept voluntary and uncompensated services from Task Force members. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services from Task Force members. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement, with administrative support provided by the Department of Health and Human Services. Health and Human Services will provide administrative support to the Task Force. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Task Force for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. For fiscal years 2002 through 2006, sums are authorized to be appropriated for an awareness campaign under subsection (h)(3) totaling $3,000,000 annually. Amounts appropriated shall remain available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Subpart 2--Organ Procurement. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for organ donor program purposes. The Internal Revenue Code now allows disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378 by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
